Authors:
Chanintorn Doungsa-ard, Alistair Ross McTaggart, Roger G.
Shivas, Andrew D.W. Geering
Title:
Phylogeny and host ranges of Uromycladium notabile and a
novel species on Acacia trudgeniana in Western Australia
Journal: Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi
Keywords:
Botrycephalae subclade, Uromycladium notabile,
Uromycladium sp. O, Pileolariaceae, Pucciniales, systematics,
taxonomy
Abstract:
Uromycladium notabile and U. tepperianum sensu lato are
widespread gall forming rusts on Australian species of Acacia.
Uromycladium notabile differs from species in the U. tepperianum complex
by having teliospores covered with warts rather than striae. A lectotype
and epitype for U. notabile on A. dealbata are proposed in this study in
order to stabilise the taxonomy of this group of rust fungi. A combined
morphological and molecular approach showed that U. notabile has a wide
host range as it was found on six Acacia species namely, A. dealbata, A.
decurrens, A. elata, A. mearnsii, A. penninervis and A. rubida.
Differences in morphology, host species and DNA sequence data of four
gene regions from the Small Subunit, the Internal transcribed Spacer and
the Large Subunit regions of nuclear ribosomal DNA, as well as the
mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit 3 showed that Uromycladium sp.
O represented a new species on A. trudgeniana in Western Australia.
